Prologue

Fish Season I is the first project that my team of three and I carried from initial concept, through prototyping and full production, all the way to publishing on Steam. It marks not only my first completed commercial release, but also the first project where I led a team from start to finish.

Meanwhile, the waters grow increasingly treacherous. Stay sharp, move fast, and fight to become the champion of this year's FISH SEASON!

details.body:
RoboShift is a first-person base-defense brawler where the player must defeat the level‚Äôs boss while also protecting their base from waves of enemies. After waking up from a coma, you find yourself abandoned on a remote planet. Due to complications with the AI responsible for the terraforming effort, the colony was abruptly evacuated. Now stranded and equipped with a bionic arm capable of crafting advanced contraptions, you must uncover what happened and find a way back to civilization.

This project is a joint effort between me and a guy named More.
We spent the last two years building the world, refining the mechanics, and getting the project off the ground.
Unfortunately, due to external factors, we decided to pause development on RoboShift for the time being. No updates or new insights are planned for now.

If the project ultimately goes nowhere, it will be released publicly ‚Äî and you are welcome to use it however you wish. The link to the repository will be published here.

name: RTS Game
description: A hobby project used to experiment with multi-layer AI using a Minimax-based decision system and AI-driven unit behavior. On the challenges was to create a general interface so that both AI and Player can control the units.

details.body:
A Strategy game made using Unity 2018.2.12f1 (64-bit) where the player controls an army of troops and the goal is to destroy the enemy base while defending yours.


Project Ghoul

As a way to learn about video game AI, I made an RTS (Real-Time Strategy) game where the player controls a small army with the goal of destroying the enemy's main army building. The core of the game consists of individual units with their own AI, allowing them to make decisions, and a larger army manager that organizes and sorts them as it passes down orders from the player or the AI. The enemy AI uses a simple minimax algorithm that translates the battlefield into a tree of possible choices, each assigned a value. This system gives the AI the flexibility to plan ahead and respond to the player's behavior while remaining performance efficient. To implement many of these systems, I relied on features of .NET and C#, such as events and delegates, to allow units to subscribe and unsubscribe to receive orders from the manager as they are being selected.


Link to the video demo: here


How To Play

  1. ‚óè 1. Use the right mouse button to select the troop you want to move and the left mouse button to click where you want it to move.
  2. ‚óè 2. Hold left shift while clicking the right mouse button on troops to control multiple troops at the same time.
  3. ‚óè 3. Click on the base to buy more units.
  4. ‚óè 4.Capture resource points to secure more resources for your army.
  5. ‚óè 5. Move the mouse cursor to the edges of the screen to move the camera.

name: Tetris_ESP32
description: My University Graduation Project: Tetris that runs a python interpretor that run on a an ESP32 micro controller. with a PS2 controller to boot.

details.body:
Description

Tetris ESP32 is my university final project. It‚Äôs a custom-built Tetris machine powered by an ESP-32 microcontroller and controlled using a PS2 game controller. Under the hood, the controller runs a MicroPython interpreter that reads, decodes, and executes Python scripts in real time, allowing us to modify, add, or remove code as needed.


PS2 Controller

The PlayStation 2 controller uses the SPI protocol for communication, which the ESP32 supports. This allows us to read ‚Äî and occasionally write ‚Äî data to the controller.


Wi-Fi

For an extra challenge, I decided that in order to view high scores from all players, the ESP32 should connect to Wi-Fi and display them through a browser interface. In the game's options menu, there is a ‚ÄúNetwork‚Äù option that lets the ESP32 connect to any nearby Wi-Fi network.


Tetris

There isn‚Äôt much to say ‚Äî it‚Äôs Tetris, or at least a close version of it. The game itself was originally an older project of mine written in C++. Feeling confident that I could adapt it, and knowing that squares are the easiest thing to draw on the screen, it was the perfect fit for our project.

name: Minecraft World Generator
description: A prototype built to explore 3D engines and rendering pipelines. build a custom C++ game engine with OpenGL for terrain generation and rendering. Implements Perlin noise for procedural terrain creation.

details.body:
This is a prototype I made to learn about 3D engines and the rendering pipeline. It is a small application that procedurally generates terrain similar to the terrain in the game Minecraft.


Built Points

  • ‚óè Terrain is divided into small chunks of 100x100x256 blocks that are stored in memory using a key-value pair (key: chunk position, value: memory address).
  • ‚óè World rendering is done using the OpenGL rendering API and shader scripts that dictate the flow of data to and from the GPU.
  • ‚óè Custom game engine handles data sorting and provides simple first-person controls to explore the generated terrain.
  • ‚óè The application uses a Perlin noise algorithm to generate the continuous terrain.

Dependencies

To compile the project, you will need to link the following libraries:

    ‚óèGLFW, GLEW for OpenGL
  • ‚óè libnoise for the Randomizer
  • ‚óè SOIL2 for handling images

name: NES_emulator
description: This Emulator is build using only standrd library. Sow you can use what ever graphics and input library you want

details.body:
NES Emulator Project

This project is a full software recreation of the Nintendo Entertainment System, built to understand how classic hardware works from the ground up. It replicates the internal behavior of the console through cycle-accurate emulation, allowing NES games to run as they would on the original system.

The emulator simulates key components of the NES:

CPU Emulation:
Implements the 6502 processor, handling opcodes, addressing modes, registers, stack operations, interrupts, and clock timing. The CPU executes instructions cycle by cycle, ensuring accurate synchronization with the rest of the system.

PPU (Picture Processing Unit):
Replicates the NES graphics hardware, including background rendering, sprite evaluation, palette handling, scroll registers, and the full 262-scanline pipeline. This enables correct drawing of tiles, sprites, and frame updates.

APU (Audio Processing Unit):
Simulates the system‚Äôs audio channels‚Äîpulse, triangle, noise, and DMC. Although simplified, it mimics the logic that generates NES-style sound output.

Cartridge & Mapper System:
Supports loading NES ROMs and interpreting their metadata. Implements mapper logic to handle bank switching, memory mirroring, and game-specific hardware behavior.

Memory Bus & Timing:
Coordinates communication between CPU, PPU, cartridge, and RAM. Ensures accurate cycle-level timing so instructions and rendering stay synchronized.

Debugging & Display Tools:
Includes optional visualization components such as CPU state monitoring, tile viewer prototypes, and test ROM compatibility for diagnosing accuracy.

This emulator was created as a hands-on learning experience‚Äîan exploration into how low-level hardware, assembly execution, and real-time rendering work together in a classic game console.

name: Tetris
description: This project is was made to as a way to learn the basics of making games And the princibls of games developments and framework. This project use the OLC Pixel Game Engine to render the game on to the screen.

details.body:
This project was my first attempt at creating a complete, fully functional application from scratch.
It brought together skills from multiple disciplines, including core game-development principles and object-oriented programming.

The project was built using C++ on a Windows machine. As a low-level language with direct access to memory, C++ provides high performance and precise control over how data is managed‚Äîat the cost of increased complexity, which in this case was a welcome challenge.

Throughout development, I learned how to structure real-time systems, manage game loops, handle input efficiently, and design reusable classes for gameplay logic. Implementing Tetris mechanics helped deepen my understanding of collision handling, grid management, timing control, and rendering optimizations.

Overall, this project served as a foundational learning experience that strengthened my confidence in building more advanced systems and understanding how games work internally.

name: The Assaulters
description: A simple tower defence game inspired by the world war 2 media. made from scratch using Blender 2.49

details.body:
Description

This is the first game I ever created ‚Äî a small tower-defense experience inspired by the opening scene of the movie Saving Private Ryan. You play as the defenders holding the beach against incoming waves of enemies. The longer you survive, the tougher and more varied the enemy forces become.



All in One

All models, rigs, scripting, and animations were made in Blender. As a kid, this was incredibly handy ‚Äî everything existed in one place, making the workflow very easy. I could create models in one scene and immediately use them in the game in another. This is also where I first learned about key concepts like frame-time optimization and basic event systems.



Programming

Once all the assets were created, I needed a way to control their logic. Fortunately, Blender had the solution built in. Back then, Blender included a node-based logic editor. It was rough, mostly good for simple logic, while the finer adjustments were handled through Python scripts. For me, it was perfect ‚Äî all game events and inputs were managed through this system, from menu logic to the level manager to the player controller.



How to Play

  1. ‚óè Use the mouse to aim the machine gun.
  2. ‚óè Right-click to fire the machine gun.
  3. ‚óè Left-click to call in artillery support (has a cooldown, so use it wisely).
  4. ‚óè Press TAB to pause the game.

name: Rough Shinobi (GlobalGameJam2026)
description: Imagine a world where every person is a ninja, bound to the power of a mask. You stand alone, driven by hatred. Explore the world, fight rival ninjas, claim their masks, and master their abilities to win it all.

details.body:
As part of the Global Game Jam 2026 competition, me and a couple of friends from the industry came together to make this game.
This year the theme for the competition was "Masks".

Rough Shinobi is a 2D platformer centered around a ninja that fights other ninjas. The main goal of the game is to reach the end of the level. This is accomplished by using power masks. Each enemy carries a mask that gives them power; by killing them, you can pick up the mask and wear it, gaining its power.
With a full set of 2D controls, a simple system, and an extra slot for holding an additional mask, it offers a full and challenging experience.

In this project I took the role of general programmer and game developer, handling all the technical tasks: code structure, implementing core game mechanics, and bug fixes.
My team‚Äôs responsibility was mainly creating art, VFX, and animation, with AI supplementing the rest, such as placeholders and audio.

name: Linux Utility Scripts
description: A collection of shell scripts for every day linux use. install, uninstal apps, select gpu type ext...

details.body:
Description

This repository is a collection of shell scripts I've created over time for everyday use on my Linux machines.



auto-install.sh

Auto-install is a script that takes binary application files and installs them on the machine.
It does this by copying the binary file into /opt/[name-of-the-program] and creating an alias for ease of use in the terminal.

Usage:

./install_app.sh [source_file_or_folder] [app_name] [-f] [-d]

Examples:

./install_app.sh ~/Downloads/Etcher.AppImage etcher
./install_app.sh ~/Downloads/balenaEtcher-linux-x64 balena-etcher -f -d

Flags:

-f  Force reinstall (delete old files before installing)
-d  Copy the entire folder (including dependencies)



uninstall.sh

Removes any program that was installed using auto-install.sh.

Usage:

./uninstall_app.sh [app_name] [-f]

Examples:

./uninstall_app.sh balena-etcher
./uninstall_app.sh etcher -f

Removes:

- /opt/[app_name] (folder or single file)
- /usr/local/bin/[app_name] (symlink)

Flags:

-f  Skip confirmation.



run_nvidia.sh / run_intel.sh

Force programs to run using a specific GPU.

Usage:

Nvidia: ./run_nvidia.sh [app_name]
Intel: ./run_intel.sh [app_name]

name: Portfolio Website Template
description: Template Website that can be easly changed and adopted to sute the need of the user

details.body:
Description

This project is a fully featured portfolio website template built in React. It is designed to help anyone quickly create and publish their own personal website with minimal setup. The template provides a clean structure, a modern layout, and easy customization so users can focus on presenting their work and identity.



Goals and Purpose

- Provide an accessible starting point for people with little or no frontend experience.
- Offer a modern, responsive design that works across all devices.
- Allow users to customize their personal website by editing simple data files or React components.
- Demonstrate how to structure a professional personal website using React.



Features

Modern and Responsive UI
Clean and minimal design that works seamlessly on mobile, tablet, and desktop.

Built with React
Component-based architecture with reusable, modular code that is easy to extend.

Dynamic Project Viewer
Loads projects from JSON or local files, includes built-in filtering and search, and supports detailed project pages with images, videos, and descriptions.

Smooth Animations
Uses Framer Motion to create fluid section transitions and animated UI elements.

Easy Content Editing
Sections such as About Me, Projects, and Skills can be edited without any backend setup.

Hash-Based Routing
Fully compatible with static hosting platforms like GitHub Pages.

Lightweight and Fast
Optimized build, efficient asset loading, and minimal dependencies.



How To

Add Projects/Timeline:
The website loads a JSON file from the web that stores all website data. This allows you to change the content of the website without touching its code.
The JSON file URLs can be found in: src/constants/index.js under the variables PROJECTS_FILE_URL and TIMELINE_FILE_URL.
Example files Projects.json and Experience.json are also included.

Change Colors
To change the website's color theme, go to the root folder and open the tailwind.config file. This file controls all colors used in the website ‚Äî from backgrounds to text.



My Role

I developed the entire frontend from the ground up, including UI and layout design, component structure, navigation and routing, mobile-first design, animation setup, performance optimizations, and deployment configuration. This project strengthened my understanding of reusable component patterns, UI design, and modern frontend workflows.

name: Factory Employee Management System
description: Developed an HTTPS-based web server for managing employees in a factory, built using the Node.js framework with an Express server architecture.

details.body:
Description

My Node.js mid-project in Yaniv Arad's Fullstack course. This project is a simple backend system designed to manage the status and shifts of workers in a factory. It uses a local JSON file and an external MongoDB database to store catalog data and update the various states of an employee. It also handles login for both administrators and users using JSON Web Tokens and adjusts access accordingly.



Summary

  • HTTPS API ‚Äì Full implementation of the HTTPS API for server-based communication.
  • JSON ‚Äì Support for saving local settings and admin info.
  • MongoDB ‚Äì Handles all database heavy lifting, including saving, sorting, and finding employees.
  • JSON Web Tokens ‚Äì End-to-end encryption for secure access to various server functions.
